from __future__ import with_statement
import sys
import codecs

def main():
    if len(sys.argv) != 2:
        print >> sys.stderr, "Usage: %s <encoding>" % sys.argv[0]
        sys.exit(1)

    encoding = sys.argv[1]
    try:
        codec = codecs.lookup(encoding)
    except LookupError:
        print "Unsupported encoding: %s" % encoding
        return

    for line in sys.stdin:
        line = line.decode(codec)
        print line

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

The F-test is significant
at the level of 0.5

If you want to be more precise, you can say something like this:

O teste F é estatisticamente significativo

Cannot commit service

A:

The problem is that you are trying to translate the word "service", which is a noun, into a verb. You can do this by adding an auxiliary verb to the end of the sentence. For example, if you want to say "I cannot commit the service", you would say:

Je ne peux pas commiter le service.

In your case, you need to add the auxiliary verb "to be able to" before the noun "service":

Je suis incapable de commiter ce service.

Note that there is a difference between being able to do something and having the ability to do it.

make[4]: *** No rule to make target `%s', needed by `%s'.  Stop.

A:

The problem here is that you are trying to run make on a file that does not exist. You can fix this by changing your makefile to look like this:
%.o: %.c
    $(CC) $(CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<

This will tell make to compile the source file and then create an object file from it.

Modify LDAP directory

A:

The problem is that you are trying to translate an English sentence into another language. You need to learn how to translate from one language to another, not vice versa.
If you want to translate something from English to French, for example, you would start by translating each word in the sentence into French. Then you would put them all together and see if it makes sense. If it doesn't make sense, then you would go back and try to figure out what went wrong.
